title-group.article-title: The sensory profile of students with probable developmental coordination disorder (DCD)

contrib-group.aff: https://ror.org/03qxff017grid.9619.70000 0004 1937 0538School of Occupational Therapy, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Israel

abstract.p: Developmental coordination disorder (DCD) in children often co-occurs with sensory processing difficulties, which exacerbate the negative ramifications of DCD. Yet the evidence of this co-occurrence in adults is limited. The aim of this study is to compare the sensory profiles of typically developing (TD) and probable-DCD (pDCD) adults, while controlling for attention deficits, which is prevalent in this population. This study followed a cross-sectional comparative and correlational design. A sample of 225 university students was divided into two groups based on the cutoff score of the Adolescents & Adults Coordination Questionnaire (pDCD score > 26, (1–1.65 SD). Sixty-three and 162 students were assigned to the pDCD and typically developing groups, respectively. All participants completed the Adolescent/Adult Sensory Profile (AASP) and an attention symptoms questionnaire. Significant group effects were found on all sensory systems of the AASP, except for taste/smell. Furthermore, students with pDCD showed significantly more deficits on the registration and sensitivity quadrants, even when attention was controlled. The findings of high prevalence of sensory processing difficulties among university students with pDCD support the theoretical assumptions related to co- occurrence between these disorders as reported in previous limited studies. These results demonstrate the importance of assessing the sensory profile of this population and providing intervention accordingly.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Developmental coordination disorder (DCD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by an impairment in motor coordination, which negatively affects academic achievement, activities of daily living, psychosocial functioning and leisure1. Individuals are often classified as having probable DCD (pDCD) if one or more of the DSM (APA, 2022) criteria for diagnosing DCD has not been formally evaluated2. The prevalence of DCD among children ranges between 5–10%1. Among college students it is estimated that 7% have pDCD3 affecting daily functioning, as well as secondary psychosocial difficulties and reduced quality of life (QoL)2.

Apart from the core motor deficits, DCD is often associated with various co-occurring neurodevelopmental disorders, for example attention deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD)2,4. Co-occurring deficits have important implications for the diagnosis, evaluation and treatment of individuals with DCD2 because they may result in a range of additional behavioral manifestations5 and enhancement of each deficit’s symptoms6. Among the co- occurring deficits individuals with DCD often have difficulties in sensory processing7.

One of the hypotheses for explaining DCD relates to the internal model of movement. (e.g., 7,8). An accurate internal model is dependent on the quality of sensory information coming into the central nervous system. It then relies on that information being effectively collated and stored, and finally on the information being retrieved in a timely manner to support forward planning. Sensory processing is one component that, along with attention, cognition and motor skills, supports self-regulation and organization of movement and behavior9.

Sensory Processing Disorder (SPD) is a heterogeneous dysfunction that affects the way that the nervous system manages incoming sensory information, including the reception, modulation, integration, perception and organization of sensory stimuli. Three primary patterns of the disorder have been proposed: sensory discrimination disorder, sensory-based motor disorder and sensory modulation disorder (SMD)10. The component of sensory modulation relates specifically to the regulatory aspect of sensory processing. Individuals with difficulties in sensory modulation experience difficulty responding to sensory stimuli in a graded and adaptive manner, relative to the degree, nature, or intensity of the sensory input10.

Across studies there is differing terminology to describe classifications of sensory processing difficulties11. One terminology, which relates specifically to the regulatory component of sensory processing, is portrayed in Dunn’s model of sensory processing12,13, which is based on the relationship between a person’s neurological threshold and the behavioral responses derived from their self-regulation strategies. Thresholds (the sensory processing aspect) range from low (quick to detect stimulation) to high (slow to detect stimulation), and self-regulation strategies (the behavioral responses) range from passive (characterized by a tendency to let stimuli happen and then respond, without an effort to reduce or increase the stimulation) to active (attempts to control the amount and type of sensory input an individual encounters). Based on this interaction, Dunn’s model suggests the existence of four sensory processing quadrants. Two quadrants are linked to sensory over-responsivity; Sensitivity (low threshold and passive self-regulation) and Avoiding (low threshold and active self-regulation), both characterized by more intense and prolonged responses to sensory stimuli. Individuals with sensory over-responsivity experience otherwise benign sensations as aversive, distracting and even painful, with variation between those who passively endure the overwhelming sensation and those who actively avoid sensory stimulation. The additional two quadrants are linked to under-responsivity; Registration (high threshold and passive self-regulation) and Seeking (high threshold and active self-regulation) - and are associated with the failure to detect sensation, with variation between those who passively endure the lack of sensation and those who are actively seeking sensory stimulation12,13. Research indicates that difficulties in sensory modulation significantly decreases function and participation across daily life activities, for both children14 and adults15. It also negatively affects QOL16 and emotional stability17.

Various studies have related to the different patterns of sensory processing disorders, mostly among children with DCD7,18, emphasizing mainly difficulties in the component of sensory perception (discrimination), in the visual, kinesthetic19, somatosensory and vestibular systems20. In contrast, relatively few studies have compared the sensory modulation component of children with and without DCD. Existing research utilizing the Sensory Profile questionnaire - an assessment based on Dunn’s model of sensory processing - indicate that children with DCD show differences in three or four of the sensory quadrants: registration18,20,21, sensitivity20–22, avoiding20,22 and seeking22. Ringold et al.22 also reported that 31% of the DCD group showed sensory over-responsivity difficulties, in comparison to 4% of the TD group.

Furthermore, studies reveal that when children with DCD have co-occurring deficits, they tend to exhibit a distinct sensory profile. For example, Delgado-Lobete et al.21 compared children aged 6–12 years with pDCD, probable ADHD (pADHD), and with co-occurring pDCD and pADHD to a group of TD children. They found that unlike the TD group, the other groups showed sensory processing differences across all four quadrants on the Short Sensory Profile questionnaire. Notably, scores were significantly higher in the pADHD and the combined condition group than the pDCD only group. The study highlighted that passive self-regulation profiles were associated with motor deficits, whereas inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity were associated specifically with the seeking quadrant, demonstrating an active self-regulation profile among children in the pADHD group. Therefore, variability in sensory processing in DCD needs to be tailored when assessing and planning interventions, both when the disorders occur independently and when there is co-occurrence7.

To our knowledge, only one study explored the co-occurrence of sensory modulation difficulties in adults with DCD23. Although this study did not compare the participants to a control group, the authors reported that the mean score of the DCD group on the Adolescent/Adult Sensory Profile questionnaire was in the range of suspected sensory processing difficulties in all sensory processing quadrants. Furthermore, the study found a significant relationship between the sensory sensitivity quadrant and anxiety traits and loneliness23. In summary, there are notably limited studies investigating sensory modulation difficulties among adults with DCD. The aims of this study were to: (a) Compare the sensory profiles of young adults with and without pDCD, and (b) to describe the percentage of young adults (with and without pDCD) with clinically significant differences in sensory modulation. Given the co-occurrence of DCD and sensory modulation difficulties with ADHD, the analysis controlled for deficits in ADHD symptomology.

sec.title: Design and participants
sec.p: This study followed a cross-sectional comparative and correlational design on a random sample of 225 university students (91% first year students), implying normative cognition,

This cross-sectional comparative and correlational study included a random sample of 225 university students (91% first-year students) with normative cognition based on self-report. Exclusion criteria included receipt of special educational services, mental health problems, or neurodevelopmental disorders other than ADHD (including learning disorders and autism spectrum disorder).

Three groups were formed from this sample, based on the cutoff scores of the Adolescents and Adults Coordination Questionnaire (AAC-Q24 see below): Students without pDCD, students, with borderline DCD and probable DCD. Yet, preliminary analysis indicated no significant differences between the two DCD groups with respect to the dependent variables. Therefore, we combined these groups’ results (henceforth, pDCD). For the sample size calculation, we first estimated in a pilot study of 40 students the ratio of pDCD and BpDCD students. The pilot study demonstrated that students with pDCD and BpDCD accounted for approximately 25% of the sample. The sample size was estimated using G-Power showing that 228 participants were required to achieve a medium effect size, alpha of 0.05 and power of 90% in comparing the two groups with a ratio of 3/1 in the number of participants. We chose a medium effect size, since this is the first study to examine SMD in adults with pDCD and therefore we had no prior estimate of effect size. In the final sample, sixty-three students were identified with pDCD (48 females; Mage = 23.18, based on 61 participants due to missing data), and 162 were non-pDCD controls (112 female; Mage = 23.22, based on 155 participants due to missing data). Due to the high prevalence of comorbidity of ADHD, which is characteristic of this population, participants with ADHD symptoms were not excluded. The groups did not differ in gender, χ2(1) = 1.10, p = 0.30, nor age t(214) = 0.12, p = 0.91.

sec.title: Identifying pDCD
sec.p: The Adolescents and Adults Coordination Questionnaire (AAC-Q)24 is a reliable and valid self-report measure, developed to screen for motor coordination deficits among adolescents and young adults. It consists of 12-items, each scored on a 1–5 Likert scale, relating to performance in motor-based everyday activities (total score ranges between 12 and 60 – higher scores indicate worse functioning). A score > 26 (i.e., 1–1.65 SD) indicates borderline DCD and a score ≥ 32 (i.e., higher than 1.65 SD) indicates probable DCD.

sec.title: Controlling for ADHD symptoms
sec.p: With the purpose of controlling for ADHD symptoms, the Wender-Utah Rating Scale (WURS)25 was used, to determine the presence and severity of ADHD symptoms. It is a reliable and valid self-report questionnaire, consisting of 61 items of which 25 are used to differentiate adults with ADHD from a non-patient comparison group. Each item is measured on a 5-point Likert scale, from 0 (not at all or very slightly) to 4 (very much). A score of 46 or higher is the recommended cutoff score indicating attention and hyperactivity difficulties.

sec.title: Sensory profile
sec.p: The sensory profile of the participants was measured using the Adolescent /Adult Sensory Profile (AASP)26that is based on Dunn’s model of sensory processing12. In this 60-item reliable and valid self-report questionnaire, individuals rate their responses to sensory experiences in daily life, pertaining to six sensory systems: auditory, tactile, visual, taste/smell, movement, and activity level. Each item is ranked on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (almost never) to 5 (almost always). The items are classified into four quadrants, reflecting different sensory processing patterns: Registration, Seeking, Sensitivity and Avoiding. The quadrant scores are interpreted relative to norms in 5 categories: (a) much less than others (> 2 standard deviation [SD]), (b) less than others (1 SD to 2 SD below the mean), (c) just like the majority of others - typical performance (± 1 SD), (d) more than others (1 SD to 2 SD above the mean), and (e) much more than others (< 2 SD). In the present study, the five ranges for each sensory processing quadrant, as presented in the AASP manual, were merged to 3 ranges as follows: “Less than most people” represents approximately 16% of the population (one standard deviation [SD] below the mean); (2) “Similar to most people” represents the normal range found among approximately 68% of the population (between − 1 SD and + 1 SD); and (3) “More than most people” represents approximately 16% of the population (more than 1 SD above the mean). The score obtained for each quadrant ranges from 5 to 75, and higher scores indicate more extreme sensory patterns.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Approval to perform this study was granted by the Hebrew university ethics committee. Participants were recruited through notices posted around the university’s campus. Those who were interested, contacted the research coordinator, signed an informed consent form and subsequently completed the questionnaires. All methods were performed in accordance with the relevant guidelines and regulations.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: All statistical calculations were performed by the Statistical Package for Social Sciences for Windows (version 26; SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) and a type I error rate of 0.05 was used for all statistical analyses. The dependent variables were examined for normality of distribution, showing that the skewness and kurtosis values were less than 1.96 (p > 0.05) (min–max 0.02–0.62). Group differences were analyzed using multivariate and univariate analyses of variance (MANOVA/ANOVA). The WURS was used as a covariate in a Multivariate analysis of covariance (MANCOVA) to explore the impact of ADHD symptoms on the main group effects. The correlations between the WURS and the AAC-Q and the AASP were examined using Pearson correlation coefficients. Finally, Chi square tests were used to compare the different profiles of sensory processing across the experimental groups.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The scores of the AASP were examined in two MANOVAs, one comparing the two groups on the six sensory systems, and the second comparing the groups on the four quadrants defined by the AASP. The results are presented in Table 1. For one participant in the pDCD group, the AASP Taste/Smell sum score was missing, and the AASP tactile sum score was missing for one participant in the control group. Consequently, the first MANOVA was based on 161 participants in the control group and 62 in the pDCD group. Examining the sensory systems, the MANOVA yielded a significant overall Group effect, F(6,216) = 10.43, p < 0.001, Wilk’s Λ = 0.775, ηp2 = 0.225. Further examination of the six systems showed significant group effects on all systems except for Taste/Smell. The second MANOVA, which focused on the four quadrants showed a significant overall group effect, F(4,220) = 19.98, p < 0.001, Wilk’s Λ = 0.734, ηp2 = 0.266, as well as significant group effects on the Registration, Sensitivity and Avoiding quadrants (see Table 1).

caption.p: Means, standard deviations and MANOVA results of group differences in the AASP raw scores.

table-wrap-foot.p: AASP = Adolescent /Adult Sensory Profile; DCD = Developmental coordination disorder.

sec.p: In subsequent analyses, the percentage of young adults classified with clinically significant differences was calculated for each of the four quadrants, according to the three categories described above, “Less than most people”, “Similar to most people” and “More than most people” (see Table 2). While the distribution of participants from the two groups was similar in the Seeking and Avoiding quadrants, the distributions diverged in the Registration and Sensitivity quadrants. In the Registration quadrant, 52.4% of the participants in the pDCD group were identified as having more symptoms than most people, as opposed to only 10.5% in the control group. In the Sensitivity quadrant, 49.2% of the participants in the pDCD group were identified as having more symptoms than most people, compared to 23.5% in the control group. This pattern of results was verified in a series of four Chi square tests for each quadrant. The tests were significant for the Registration and Sensitivity quadrants χ2(2) = 52.65, p < 0.001 and χ2(2) = 16.38, p < 0.001, respectively, but not for the Seeking and Avoiding quadrants χ2(2) = 0.40, p = 0.82 and χ2(2) = 2.22, p = 0.33, respectively.

caption.p: Number (and %) of participants in each quadrant of the AASP for the probable DCD and control groups.

table-wrap-foot.p: AASP = Adolescent/Adult Sensory Profile; DCD = Developmental coordination disorder.

sec.p: Because both DCD and sensory modulation difficulties are typically associated with ADHD, it was important to control for these symptoms. Consistent with these observations, in the current sample, the WURS total score was correlated significantly with the AAC-Q and with the AASP visual, auditory and level of activity systems, and with the four quadrants of the AASP showing small to medium correlations27 (see Table 3). Therefore, we ran two MANCOVAs on the AASP scores, with the WURS total score as a covariate (see Table 4). The first MANCOVA demonstrated that the overall group effect on the sensory systems remained significant F(6,214) = 7.32, p < 0.001, Wilk’s Λ = 0.830, ηp2 = 0.170, as were the group effects on all sensory systems except Taste/Smell. The second MANCOVA, which examined group differences in the four AASP quadrants remained significant as well F(4,218) = 13.99, p < 0.001, Wilk’s Λ = 0.796, ηp2 = 0.204, as were the group main effects on the Registration and Sensitivity quadrants. The group effect on the Avoiding quadrant was no longer significant in this analysis. Thus, participants in the pDCD group showed difficulties in sensory processing that went beyond ADHD symptoms.

caption.p: Pearson correlation coefficients between the WURS, AAC-Q and the sensory systems and quadrants of the AASP.

table-wrap-foot.p: AAC-Q = The Adolescents & Adults Coordination Questionnaire; WURS = Wender-Utah Rating Scale; AASP = Adolescent/Adult Sensory Profile.

caption.p: Estimated marginal means, standard errors and the results of the MANCOVA, examining groups effects on the AASP scores, with the Wender Utah rating scale (WURS) as a covariate.

table-wrap-foot.p: AASP = Adolescent/Adult Sensory Profile; DCD = Developmental coordination disorder.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The main aim of this study was to expand the existing knowledge of the co-occurrence of DCD and difficulties in sensory modulation among children, by comparing the sensory profiles of young adults with and without pDCD. This study showed that compared to typically developing students, those with pDCD scored higher on all sensory systems, except for Taste/Smell. Students with pDCD also scored higher on the Registration, Sensitivity and Avoiding quadrants of the AASP. Interestingly, when controlling for ADHD symptoms, the group difference in the Avoiding quadrant was no longer significant. Further analysis indicated that nearly half of the pDCD group showed clinically significant differences in the registration and sensitivity quadrants; a significantly higher rate than in the control group. Thus, the findings underscore the persistence of co-occurrence of pDCD and sensory modulation difficulties in adulthood, highlighting that young adults with pDCD (with ADHD symptoms controlled) display either low or high thresholds, with a passive self-regulation profile.

The association between pDCD (controlled for ADHD symptoms) and sensory modulation difficulties are consistent with research on children with DCD, showing similar sensory profiles, with deficits mainly in the registration and sensitivity quadrants, indicating a passive self-regulation profile18,21. Studies on children suggested that the passive sensory self-regulation in DCD might be related to difficulties in proprioceptive/kinesthetic performance, common in DCD28, which play a crucial role in the development of motor control and performance29. These enable children to learn, adapt and plan their movements, and regulate their behavior actively according to their neurological threshold21.

Studies have also found proprioceptive/kinesthetic deficits in adult DCD29. Similar to children, these deficits can possibly explain the passive sensory behavior strategies found in this current study, as expressed in the registration and sensitivity quadrants12,13. Thus, passive sensory behavior in adults with pDCD may be explained, in part, by deficits in proprioception, which impact their body movement awareness and motor feedback, and can limit their active sensory behavior and their resistance to their neurologic thresholds.

Due to the high co-occurrence between DCD and ADHD2 we controlled for these symptoms. It is interesting that without controlling these symptoms, pDCD was associated with the Avoiding quadrant, an active self-regulation profile, described in the literature as a characteristic of individuals with ADHD20,21. The active behavior can be explained by the tendency of individuals with ADHD to pay more attention to sensory stimuli in their environment and consequently attempt therefore to avoid them30. As concluded by Delgado-Lobete et al.21; passive self-regulation sensory profiles were associated with the behavior of children with deficits in motor performance, whereas the behavior of children with inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity symptoms was associated with active sensory self-regulation.

In addition to analyzing the disparities in the sensory quadrant scores among the study groups, we further examined differences in their respective sensory system scores. Participants with pDCD showed higher scores on all sensory systems in the AASP, except for Taste/Smell. These results align with studies that compared sensory modulation abilities of children with DCD and typically developing children, and found higher scores in all sensory systems7,20. The non-significant group differences in the Taste/Smell systems has not been shown previously in adults. Possibly, contrary to children, adults have more control over their behavior and their environment, including what they eat, and the scents they are exposed to, allowing them to avoid unpleasant environments and food products.

In summary, Gilger and Kaplan31 developed a framework of Atypical Brain Development (ABD) that claims that the overlap of symptoms across multiple NDDs is frequent enough to suggest that they share a common etiology32. The results of this study support the growing evidence demonstrating a high prevalence of co-occurrence among NDDs1and its persistence into adulthood. Specifically, this study reinforces the co-occurrence of pDCD and sensory modulation difficulties showing, on the one hand, the unique sensory patterns of young adults with pDCD with co-occurring ADHD symptoms, and on the other hand, the unique contribution of pDCD to sensory modulation patterns beyond ADHD symptoms. Importantly, even after statistically controlling for ADHD symptoms, individuals with pDCD exhibited distinct sensory patterns, indicating that these characteristics are specifically associated with pDCD and not solely attributable to attentional deficits. Furthermore, this study supports the contention of an underlying sensory-motor mechanisms of DCD in young adults2and emphasizes the variability of sensory processing difficulties among young adults with pDCD.

sec.title: Limitations and strengths
sec.p: This study has some limitations that need to be considered. The participants were diagnosed as having pDCD based only on self-report questionnaires and not based on motor assessments such as the M-ABC-333. Most of the sample were female and were students with high academic abilities relative to the general population. Further research should include a larger representative sample and additional direct evaluation of DCD. Furthermore, our main focus in this study was pDCD, SMD and ADHD, therefore we did not screen for other potential co-occurring neurodevelopmental disorders. It is important for future studies to include screening questionnaires for additional neurodevelopmental disorders such as ASD, as well as other health conditions which may be associated with motor disorders such as low birth weight. Alongside these limitations, it is important to note that this study is among the few that have examined the co-occurrence of pDCD and SMD in the adult population. Furthermore, by controlling for ADHD symptoms, which are prevalent in individuals with DCD, the study ensures that the observed differences in sensory profiles are not confounded by attention and hyperactivity-related issues. This strengthens the validity of the findings regarding sensory processing difficulties specific to pDCD. Additionally, the use of the Adolescent/Adult Sensory Profile (AASP) provides a comprehensive and standardized measure of sensory processing.

sec.title: Conclusions and implications
sec.p: The present study contributes to the limited knowledge regarding the sensory processing patterns of young adults with pDCD, and the unique contribution of ADHD symptoms to the relation between pDCD and sensory processing. The results indicate that the co-occurrence between pDCD and sensory modulation difficulties continues into adulthood. Young adults with pDCD are more likely to react passively to their sensory-neurological threshold in comparison to young adults with pDCD and co-occurring ADHD symptoms. A better understanding of the unique sensory patterns in this population may support the development of tailored interventions. These could include raising awareness of the sensory difficulties associated with pDCD, both among students themselves through focus groups to understand in depth their special needs and academic staff; developing support groups for university students with motor and sensory difficulties; and providing effective strategies to promote their participation in university activities and help them overcome these challenges. It is also important to recognize and address co-occurring symptoms within this population.
